Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Autonomous Dynamic Power Management to Redcue Power Consumption in Data Centers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Program (SBIR) Phase I project will research autonomous, dynamic power management to reduce power consumption in data center servers by up to 15-20%, strongly supporting the Environmental Protection Agency's push toward low-power data centers and rapid adoption of the new Energy Star label for computer servers. In 2010, data centers in the United States consumed over 200 TWh of energy, making data centers one of the largest consumers of the electrical grid. This research project will launch an aggressive initiative to develop a smart power management integrated circuit that can be embedded within data center servers to conserve power on embedded memory. The research will focus on characterization of the memory power consumption, the creation of an autonomous controller to provide dynamic voltage scaling of the memory, and demonstration of advanced power management by a real-time, hardware-based power management method. If successful, the power consumption may be reduced by 15-20% with no impact to the server design, while simultaneously reducing latency, enhancing thermal management, and improving reliability. The intellectual merit is to provide an innovative autonomous power management technology with intelligent integrated circuits for scalable solutions on any computing platform, including megawatt-sized data centers.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is carbon footprint reduction and significant cost savings by addressing the overwhelming power drain by data centers, providing a substantial impact on reducing the nation's demand for electricity. Since 2006, data centers use more energy per year in the United States than televisions. In 2010, data centers used the equivalent energy of 22 million homes. The continual increase in demands for data center storage, cloud computing and processing power is predicted to drive significant growth in the number of data center servers worldwide within the next decade. This research may show that autonomous power management integrated circuits implemented in 15.6% of servers worldwide would reduce the need for an entire power plant. Leading server manufacturers are seeking new solutions in power management due to the increasing costs and environmental impacts of powering data centers. Unlike competing technologies, the "just-enough/just-in-time" solution proposed in this research uniquely saves power by monitoring activity across an entire system outside the microprocessor, delivering power only when needed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project researched autonomous, dynamic power management for data center servers and demonstrated the potential to reduce power in memory by 20 to 40%. This proposal strongly supports the EPA’s push toward low-power data centers and rapid adoption of the new Energy Star label for computer servers. In 2012, digital warehouses worldwide used about 30 billion watts of electricity, the rough equivalent to the output of 30 nuclear power plants according to a revealing New York Times article. With this research project, Packet Digital launched an initiative to develop a smart power management integrated circuit that can be embedded within data center servers to conserve power. Packet Digital developed its patented On-Demand Power® technology to reduce power consumption by monitoring systems and providing dynamic voltage scaling to all components, distributing only the amount of power needed as energy demand changes. Performance levels already demonstrated include:

  • 41.1% DDR3 memory module power savings at the motherboard on an Intel Canoe Pass Server Reference Board; verified by white box memory module manufacturer SMART Modular.
  • 15W system power savings (which translated to 4.06% at the wall!) was observed on a Cisco UCS C220-M3 server during standard Prime95 benchmark testing compared to an independent 3rd party’s best testing.
  • 13.7 degrees Celsius reduction in temperature on the Canoe Pass Server (from 53C to 39.3C).
  • Improved reliability was observed by Smart Modular during ATE testing as the bit error rate improved from the baseline run which had two 2 bank errors to zero errors with On-Demand Power technology.

The continual increase in demands for data center storage and processing power is predicted to drive significant growth in the number of data center servers worldwide within the next decade. The top overall suppliers of power management chips are Texas Instruments, Maxim, and Linear Technology.  Top server manufacturers, including HP, Dell, Cisco and Intel, are seeking new solutions in power management due to the increasing costs and environmental impacts of powering data centers. Unlike competing technologies, Packet Digital’s “just-enough/just-in-time” solution uniquely saves power by monitoring activity across an entire system outside the microprocessor, delivering power only when needed. This proposed research is an extension of our funded research in server power management and leverages our commercialization partnerships with industry leaders.

Currently Packet Digital is collaborating with two industry leaders: Cisco for servers and SMART Modular (SMART) for memory modules. The dynamic power management algorithms from Phase I have been integrated into both SMART and Cisco evaluation platforms. We have signed a Memorandum of Understanding with SMART for further development and distribution and in discussion with Cisco regarding future development.

The intellectual merit is to provide an innovative autonomous power management technology with intelligent integrated circuits for scalable solutions on any computing platform including megawatt-sized data centers. The technical challenge of integrating autonomous power management into servers is a significant undertaking requiring a high degree of innovation that has not yet been implemented in the industry.
